Rxf7 Qxf7 $4 {My hand reached out of its own accord and somehow grabbed
exactly the opposite piece to my intention.} (21... Rxf7 {is of course the
only reasonable move and the one I had intended to play.}) 22. Rf1 Qg8 23. Rxf8
Qxf8 24. Nxc7 Bg8 25. Bxb6 Qb8 26. Qf2 a4 27. Nd5 axb3 28. axb3 Qa8 29. Qf3 Kg7
30. Be3 Nd4 31. Bxd4 Bxd4 32. Nc7 Qc8 33. Nb5 Be5 34. Qe3 Qf8 35. Nc3 Be6 36.
Nd5 Bxd5 37. exd5 Qb8 38. h4 h6 $4 {is needlessly weakening.} 39. Qd3 Qd8 40.
Bh3 $4 Qxh4 41. b4 Qf6 42. Qe2 h5 43. Kg2 {here White offered a draw, and I
elected to play on and try to win the g pawn.} Qg5 44. Qf2 h4 45. Be6 hxg3 46.
Qf7+ Kh6 47. Qf8+ Kh5 48. Qf3+ Kh6 49. Qf8+ {and I used my remaining 15
minutes to attempt to find a productive line to avoid the perpetual, but I was
not able to see enough of the line included below and decided not to risk
blundering again after the earlier silliness of Qxf7.} Kh5 $2 (49... Bg7 {is
best and offers very good winning chances, as} 50. Qxd6 $4 {loses immediately.}
(50. Qf3 Qd2+ 51. Kf1 $1 {is the only move that survives!}) 50... Qd2+ 51. Kxg3
Qe3+ 52. Kg2 Qe2+ 53. Kh1 Qe4+ 54. Kg1 Bd4+ {and White either gives up the
Queen or is immediately mated.}) 50. Qf3+ Kh6 51. Qf8+ Kh5 {and the game was a
draw by threefold repetition.} 1/2-1/2

1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. c4 e6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. c5 Ne4 8. Qc2

15. a3 O-O 16. g3 Rfc8 17. Bf4 Qd8 18. Qd2 h6 19. h4 Bf6 20. a4 Bc4 21. b5 b6
22. c6 Be7 23. Qe3 Ra7 24. Kg2 {In my mind, I was securing all of my pieces 
(guarding my Knight before I go elsewhere with my Queen), playing a useful
waiting move, and clearing the Back Rank for possibilities on the h-file. In
reality, this is arguably the second-worst move of the game. My King ends up a
massive liability on the light squares.} Bb4 25. Rec1 Re7 26. Ne5 f6 27. Ng6
Re8 28. h5 $4 {totally missing what follows} e5 $1 29. Bxe5 (29. dxe5 d4 $1 30.
Qf3 Bd5 $19) (29. Bxh6 exd4 30. Qf4 gxh6 31. Qxh6 {is probably better for
practical chances.}) 29... fxe5 30. Nxe5 Bd6 31. f4 Bxe5 32. fxe5 Qg5 $4 {and
suddenly, emerging from total despair, I find a very dangerous-looking idea.}
33. Qxg5 hxg5 34. Rxc4 $1 dxc4 35. Kf3 Rf8+ 36. Ke4 Rf2 37. Rc1 Re2+ $4 38. Kd5
Kf7 39. Kd6 Ke8 40. c7 Re3 41. Rxc4 Rxg3 42. d5 Rh3 43. Kc6 Rxh5 44. Kb7 Rxc7+
45. Rxc7 (45. Kxc7 {is cleaner.}) 45... g4 {It's important to note at this
moment that my opponent was a talker. He decided to start jabbering at me
right here "Oh my god, you're playing this so well. Can you just resign or
something?" -- I'm not sure if he meant this as a genuine compliment or as a
ploy, but I completely admit it: I let pride get to me, and I played the
massive blunder which follows completely blind to the obvious reply.} 46. d6
Rxe5 47. d7+ $4 Kd8 {and while it's still winning, White has to hang around
for another 12 moves and 30 minutes.} 48. Rc8+ Kxd7 49. Rc7+ Kd8 50. Kxb6 ({I
realized at the last moment that} 50. Rxg7 $4 {is met with} Re7+ $1 $19) 50...
Re6+ 51. Kb7 Re7 52. b6 g3 53. Kb8 Re6 54. b7 Rg6 55. Rc1 g2 56. Rg1 Ra6 57.
Rxg2 g6 58. Rd2+ Ke7 59. Kc7 1-0

1. e4 c5 2. Nc3 {I have to say, the loud sighs I get from my opponents after
playing this move are both consistent and enjoyable.} d6 3. g3 Nc6 4. Bg2 Nf6
5. d3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. h3 Bd7 8. Qd2 Nd4 9. Nce2 $1 {decided to play this
after a recent discussion with Alex: instead of Nd1, this move offers Black
the chance to complete my development for me.} e5 10. c3 Nxe2 11. Nxe2 b5 $2 {
much too slow} 12. O-O O-O 13. f4 Qc7 $6 {this move is usally better after the
c-file has been opened for the Queen. Here, it was better to active Black's
Rooks or to play more actively for d5.} (13... Bc6 {is an improvement.}) 14. f5
Bc6 15. g4 $1 {preventing d5} Nd7 (15... d5 $2 16. g5 $1 d4 17. Bf2 Nh5 18. f6
$18) 16. Ng3 a5 17. Rf2 Rab8 18. Raf1 f6 {this move slows White down a bit but
now g6 is weakened, which allows White to create his outpost.} 19. h4 Rf7 20.
fxg6 hxg6 21. h5 Nf8 22. g5 $1 Qd8 (22... f5 23. hxg6 Nxg6 24. exf5 Bxg2 25.
Rxg2) 23. hxg6 Nxg6 24. Nf5 $6 (24. Nh5 $1) 24... Nf4 $4 25. Bxf4 exf4 26. Qxf4
Be8 (26... fxg5 $4 27. Nh6+) 27. Nxd6 $2 {does not give up the win, but it
deserves criticism for not being greedy enough. Any waiting move here is
better, and White is winning much more easily than in the game.} fxg5 28. Nxf7
gxf4 29. Nxd8 Rxd8 {and White is winning, but suddenly he doesn't know exactly
how to proceed--the bishops are plenty dangerous.} 30. Bh3 Rxd3 31. Be6+ Kf8
32. Rxf4+ Ke7 33. Bd5 Bh6 34. R4f3 Rd2 35. R1f2 Rd1+ 36. Kg2 Re1 37. Rf6 Be3
38. Re6+ Kd7 39. Rff6 Bh5 40. Bc6+ {was played very quickly to make time
control.} Kd8 41. Bxb5 Rb1 42. a4 Rxb2+ 43. Kg3 Rb1 44. e5 Bg5 45. Rd6+ Kc8 46.
Rf8+ Kb7 47. Rd7+ Kb6 48. Rb8# 1-0
